awd_titl_txt: Engineered Biofiltration Processes for Microcystin Removal in Drinking Water: A Structured Enzyme-Kinetic Modeling Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
Harmful algal blooms are caused by the growth of algae that produce a toxin known as microcystin. Microcystin is linked to liver cancer and is difficult to treat using conventional drinking water treatment practices. This project investigates biological filtration ("biofiltration") to remove microcystin during drinking water treatment. Biofiltration relies on natural communities of bacteria in sand filters to degrade microcystin. This research focuses on establishing a stable biofiltration treatment system under the highly variable environment of a drinking water treatment plant. The project will develop models to predict biofiltration treatment behavior with the goal of making biofiltration an effective treatment process to protect the Nation's drinking water supply. The educational program will train students in cross-disciplinary science and engineering to improve the scientific literature and the technological skills of the Nation.

The goal of this project is to develop a predictive understanding of the environmental and operational factors governing microbial community dynamics and microcystin biodegradation in biofiltration systems. The specific objectives are to: 1) quantify and compare the steady-state growth characteristics of suspended and immobilized microcystin-degrading bacterial consortia (MC-DBC) in engineered reactors; 2) define environmental and hydraulic conditions that enhance the activity and stability of the aqueous and biofilm MC-DBC in these reactor systems; and 3) investigate and compare the microbial community structure and function within each MC-DBC to gain a holistic understanding of the microbial community interactions within MC-DBC. This research will combine culture based and genetic microbiological investigations with numerical simulations of fate and transport to optimize management of algal toxin removal in biofiltration systems. The effects of various nutrient conditions on the growth and degradation kinetics of MC-DBC will directly inform biostimulation practices to improve biodegradation kinetics during harmful algal bloom periods. Integration of experimental observations with the development of a mechanistic numerical model will highlight the relative importance of enzyme induction kinetics, enzyme dilution, or enzyme regulation to biofiltration efficiency. The numerical model simulations will advance our ability to design biofiltration systems by assessing the feasibility and treatment capability of algal toxin removal over a wide range of operating conditions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The increasing frequency and severity of harmful cyanobacteria blooms, which are a direct result of global climate change and associated anthropogenic factors, present a persistent and formidable challenge to safeguarding the quality of existing and future freshwater resources nationwide. Biofiltration has the potential to offer a low-cost solution for algal toxin microcystin removal. However, inherent to any biological treatment processes, the treatment efficiency of algal toxins for most biofiltration systems are recognized to be transient in nature, as the population of native microorganisms in the source water is dynamic and constantly changing. This research examined the biodegradation behavior of isolated microcystin-degrading consortia in a series of experiments that closely represented open system, environmental conditions. The results showed that natural microcystin-degrading bacteria were commonly occurring in lake water that is used for drinking water production. These bacteria could be easily obtained using culture enrichment with microcystin in minimal media. However, the degradation kinetics were highly influenced by the presence of easily assimilable organic nutrients. The kinetic decline was associated with changes of microbial community in the consortia, shifting to a community that favors assimilable organic instead of microcystin. An adjustment of consortia isolation strategy using medium that contains both microcystin and assimilable organic nutrients yielded a unique microcystin degrading bacterial consortium that can perform microcystin degradation at high rate in the presence of assimilable organic nutrients. The consortium could also work synergistically with a pure isolate of microcystin degrading bacterium to shorten the time requirement for complete removal of microcystin. Comparison of several unstructured kinetic models to describe microcystin microbial metabolism by isolated degrading populations indicated that models incorporating mechanisms of enzyme-microcystin saturation, affinity, and cooperative binding interactions of a theoretical single, rate limiting reaction accurately and reliably predicted microcystin degradation and bacterial growth kinetics. Broadly, this study advanced the knowledge of a practical approach to removing microcystin in the environment through biodegradation. The outcomes of this research have the potential to advance biofiltration as an effective treatment process for cyanotoxin removal in municipal drinking water treatment systems. The numerical model is available to be used as a tool, alongside field monitoring programs, to guide the design and operation of engineered treatment systems. The project also provided the opportunity to undergraduate and graduate students to incorporate multidisciplinary science into the design and creation of future biofiltration systems and to address the effects of harmful algal blooms on our existing water resources.
